_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Carl Eastwood and Sons LLC
Rosenberg, TX

Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

The accidental release prevention policy at Carl Eastwood and Sons involves, but is not limited to technologies, procedures and management practices. This facility conforms to the laws and regulations of the state of Texas.  Our emergency response policy involves our cooperation with community response plans that are tailored to our facility and to the emergency response services available in our community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.

This facility is in the business of selling anhydrous ammonia to farm customers as a form of nitrogen fertilizer.  Storage tanks, nurse tanks, risers for filling nurse tanks, electrical panels, lighting, and safety equipment are all parts of this facility?s anhydrous ammonia operation.  Though facility is manned through out the year, the ammonia is sold to farmers only during spring and fall use seasons.  The facility operates with normal business hours.

The off-site consequences analysis includes two anhydrous ammonia release scenarios, identified as ?worst-case? release and ?alternative? release scenarios.  The first scenario is defined by EPA and shall assume the maximum quantity of the largest vessel is released as a gas in 10 minutes due to a catastrophic break.  The alternative release scenario is defined as a more likely accidental release of anhydrous ammonia caused by a transfer hose failure.

The results of the above off-site consequences analysis have been pulled from the executive summary but can be found in Sections 2.0 and 3.0 of the Risk Management Plan.  These analysis have been documented in the facilities Risk Management Program.

Carl Eastwood and Sons has had no anhydrous ammonia leaks within the past five years.  Even though the company has had no releases it still coordinates annual visits with the local fire department to review the systems and procedures for response to a leak.

Ca

rl Eastwood and Sons has several key elements to their accident prevention program:
1.  The anhydrous ammonia system adheres to the laws and regulations of the State of Texas.
2.  Annual training is required of all personnel on handling, transferring, or transporting anhydrous ammonia.  The training includes properties of ammonia, safe handling practices, first aid, and emergency response.
3.  Use of good management practices as specified by industry standards and training aids.
4.  Frequent site inspections by management and safety consultants.
5.  Annual inspections include safety equipment, tanks and handling equipment.
6.  Use of proper anhydrous ammonia personal protective equipment and safety equipment.

Changes are made in the system when necessary or when required by regulation change.  Periodic evaluations of the procedures help to determine whether or not a change in operations should be made to provide increased safey to the operators and to the community.
